Section 508 and NASA Presentation to GSFC Webmasters November 27, 2001
Section 508 and NASA
Presentation to GSFC Webmasters
November 27, 2001

Bob Benedict Office of the Chief Information Officer NASA Headquarters bob.benedict@hq.nasa.gov
Bob Benedict
Office of the Chief Information Officer
NASA Headquarters
bob.benedict@hq.nasa.gov

Section 508 Background
Section 508 Background

• The legal basis for Section 508 . . .
• The legal basis for Section 508 . . .

– The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 amended Section
– The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 amended Section

508 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973
508 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973

– When developing, procuring, maintaining, or using
– When developing, procuring, maintaining, or using

Electronic and Information Technology (EIT), Federal agencies must ensure that Federal employees with disabilities have access to and use of information and data that is comparable to that for other employees
Electronic and Information Technology (EIT), Federal
agencies must ensure that Federal employees with
disabilities have access to and use of information and data
that is comparable to that for other employees

– Members of the public with disabilities seeking information or services from an agency must have access to and use of information and data that is comparable to that for members of the public without disabilities
– Members of the public with disabilities seeking information
or services from an agency must have access to and use of
information and data that is comparable to that for members
of the public without disabilities

– Above requirements must be met unless to do so would
– Above requirements must be met unless to do so would

cause an “undue burden”
cause an “undue burden”

Section 508 Background
Section 508 Background

• How the law was implemented at the Federal
• How the law was implemented at the Federal

level . . . – The Architectural and Transportation Barriers
level . . .
– The Architectural and Transportation Barriers

Compliance Board (Access Board) published final EIT accessibility standards in the Federal Register, following extensive public comment and debate, on April 25, 2001
Compliance Board (Access Board) published final EIT
accessibility standards in the Federal Register,
following extensive public comment and debate, on
April 25, 2001

– The Access Board EIT accessibility standards became
– The Access Board EIT accessibility standards became

effective June 25, 2001
effective June 25, 2001

Section 508 Background
Section 508 Background

• Technology scope of Section 508 . . .
• Technology scope of Section 508 . . .

– From a technology point of view, Section 508 includes
– From a technology point of view, Section 508 includes

just about everything
just about everything

– Includes all Information Technology (IT) plus
– Includes all Information Technology (IT) plus

telecommunications products (e.g., telephones), information kiosks and transaction machines, Web sites, multimedia, and office equipment such as copiers and fax machines
telecommunications products (e.g., telephones),
information kiosks and transaction machines, Web i n f o r m a t i o n
k i o s k s
a n d
t r a n s a c t i o n
m a c h i n e s ,
W e b
sites, multimedia, and office equipment such as copiers s i t e s ,
m u l t i m e d i a ,
a n d
o f f i c e
e q u i p m e n t
s u c h
a s
c o p i e r s
and fax machines

– Excludes embedded IT such as controllers for HVAC
– Excludes embedded IT such as controllers for HVAC

and for medical equipment
and for medical equipment

Section 508 Background
Section 508 Background

• Section 508 technical standards for specific
• Section 508 technical standards for specific

technologies and products . . . – Software applications and operating systems – Web-based intranet and internet information and
technologies and products . . .
– Software applications and operating systems
– Web-based intranet and internet information and

applications
applications

– Telecommunications products – Video and multimedia products – Self contained, closed products – Desktop and portable computers
– Telecommunications products
– Video and multimedia products
– Self contained, closed products
– Desktop and portable computers

Section 508 Background
Section 508 Background

• Section 508 functional performance criteria
• Section 508 functional performance criteria

(six of these) . . . – Covers technologies or components for which there is no standard covered by the previous seven categories – E.g., technology or product does not yet exist or was
(six of these) . . .
– Covers technologies or components for which there is
no standard covered by the previous seven categories
– E.g., technology or product does not yet exist or was

not contemplated by Access Board standards
not contemplated by Access Board standards

– “(a) At least one mode of operation and information retrieval that does not require user vision shall be provided, or support for assistive technology used by people who are blind or visually impaired shall be provided”
– “(a) At least one mode of operation and information
retrieval that does not require user vision shall be
provided, or support for assistive technology used by
people who are blind or visually impaired shall be
provided”

Section 508 Background
Section 508 Background

• Section 508 information, documentation, and
• Section 508 information, documentation, and

support requirements . . . – Product support documentation provided to end-users shall be made available in alternate formats upon request, at no additional charge
support requirements . . .
– Product support documentation provided to end-users
shall be made available in alternate formats upon
request, at no additional charge

– End-user shall have access to a description of the
– End-user shall have access to a description of the

accessibility and compatibility features of products in alternate formats or alternate methods upon request, at no additional charge
accessibility and compatibility features of products in
alternate formats or alternate methods upon request, at
no additional charge

– Support services for products shall accommodate the communication needs of end-users with disabilities
– Support services for products shall accommodate the
communication needs of end-users with disabilities

Section 508 Background
Section 508 Background

• Organizational scope of Section 508 . . .
• Organizational scope of Section 508 . . .

– Applies to all Federal departments and agencies,
– Applies to all Federal departments and agencies,

including the US Postal Service
including the US Postal Service

– Applies to contractors supplying products and services
– Applies to contractors supplying products and services

to Federal departments and agencies, unless the contractor’s use of EIT is incidental to the product or service (statutory requirement is on the departments and agencies, not on the contractors)
to Federal departments and agencies, unless the
contractor’s use of EIT is incidental to the product or
service (statutory requirement is on the departments and
agencies, not on the contractors)

– Does not apply to the states, though some are aligning
– Does not apply to the states, though some are aligning

their laws with Section 508
their laws with Section 508

– Does not apply to private industry in general, e.g.,
– Does not apply to private industry in general, e.g.,

www.microsoft.com and www.sun.com do not have to be Section 508 compliant
www.microsoft.com and www.sun.com do not have to
be Section 508 compliant

Section 508 Background
Section 508 Background

• Exceptions
• Exceptions

defense
defense

– Certain systems related to national security and national
– Certain systems related to national security and national

– EIT acquired by a contractor incidental to a contract – Making compliant would cause a “fundamental
– EIT acquired by a contractor incidental to a contract
– Making compliant would cause a “fundamental

alteration” to a product
alteration” to a product

– Products located in spaces frequented only by service
– Products located in spaces frequented only by service

personnel for maintenance, repair, or occasional monitoring of equipment
personnel for maintenance, repair, or occasional
monitoring of equipment

Section 508 Background
Section 508 Background

• Section 508 enforcement provisions . . .
• Section 508 enforcement provisions . . .

– Agencies may be sued if their EIT purchases do not
– Agencies may be sued if their EIT purchases do not

comply with applicable Access Board standards unless an exception has been documented
comply with applicable Access Board standards unless
an exception has been documented

– Purchases situation applies to products and services – Apparent enforcement loophole related to web pages developed by civil service staff expected to be closed by upcoming Executive Order/Memorandum
– Purchases situation applies to products and services
– Apparent enforcement loophole related to web pages
developed by civil service staff expected to be closed
by upcoming Executive Order/Memorandum

– Also, media attention and audits by Office of Inspector
– Also, media attention and audits by Office of Inspector

General, General Accounting Office, and other oversight groups impose scrutiny on and re-enforce accountability of agencies
General, General Accounting Office, and other
oversight groups impose scrutiny on and re-enforce
accountability of agencies

Section 508 Background
Section 508 Background

• What about “undue burden”?
• What about “undue burden”?

– Concept that came out of Section 504 (requires
– Concept that came out of Section 504 (requires

accessibility to buildings, etc.)
accessibility to buildings, etc.)

– Defined as “significant difficulty or expense” – For Section 508, must consider all agency resources
– Defined as “significant difficulty or expense”
– For Section 508, must consider all agency resources

available to the relevant program or component
available to the relevant program or component

– Although case law exists for Section 504, how undue
– Although case law exists for Section 504, how undue

burden should be interpreted for Section 508 is unclear and controversial
burden should be interpreted for Section 508 is unclear
and controversial

– See NASA web policy on Section 508 for more
– See NASA web policy on Section 508 for more

information
information

– Consult with Center legal staff
– Consult with Center legal staff

Section 508 Background
Section 508 Background

• Why we should care about Section 508 . . .
• Why we should care about Section 508 . . .

– While Section 508 Is The Law, it is a law whose intent makes sense and whose thoughtful implementation will benefit federal agencies, their employees, and the public
– While Section 508 Is The Law, it is a law whose intent – W h i l e
S e c t i o n
5 0 8
I s
T h e
L a w ,
i t
i s
a
l a w
w h o s e
i n t e n t
makes sense and whose thoughtful implementation will
benefit federal agencies, their employees, and the
public

– Federal agencies must do more with fewer resources: we need the best from all our employees, including those with disabilities
– Federal agencies must do more with fewer resources:
we need the best from all our employees, including
those with disabilities

– Support for NASA’s programs requires buy-in from all segments of the American public, including citizens with disabilities
– Support for NASA’s programs requires buy-in from all
segments of the American public, including citizens
with disabilities

NASA and Federal Section 508 Community
NASA and Federal Section 508 Community

• NASA is active in the Federal Section 508
• NASA is active in the Federal Section 508

community . . . – NASA Office of Procurement (Code H) is one of the
community . . .
– NASA Office of Procurement (Code H) is one of the

drafters of the Federal Acquisition Regulations addressing Section 508
drafters of the Federal Acquisition Regulations
addressing Section 508

– The NASA CIO is a member of the Federal Section 508
– The NASA CIO is a member of the Federal Section 508

Steering Committee and the industry/government/academia Accessibility Forum – NASA Agency-level Section 508 Team co-chair is a member of the Federal Section 508 Working Group – Both NASA Agency-level Section 508 co-chairs speak
Steering Committee and the
industry/government/academia Accessibility Forum
– NASA Agency-level Section 508 Team co-chair is a
member of the Federal Section 508 Working Group
– Both NASA Agency-level Section 508 co-chairs speak

at national-level Section 508 conferences
at national-level Section 508 conferences

NASA Section 508 Team
NASA Section 508 Team

• NASA established a Section 508 team to
• NASA established a Section 508 team to

address its implementation in the Agency . . . – Representatives from every Center – Representatives from Agency-level offices: CIO,
address its implementation in the Agency . . .
– Representatives from every Center
– Representatives from Agency-level offices: CIO,

procurement, legal, EEO, human resources
procurement, legal, EEO, human resources

– Co-chaired by Charles Redmond and Bob Benedict
– Co-chaired by Charles Redmond and Bob Benedict

– Telecons every other week to share information, resolve
– Telecons every other week to share information, resolve

(HQ)
(HQ)

issues, etc.
issues, etc.

Section 508 Requirements for Web Pages
Section 508 Requirements for Web Pages

• Sixteen Section 508 Web requirements – Some are relatively straight-forward: “A text equivalent for every non-text element shall be provided”
• Sixteen Section 508 Web requirements
– Some are relatively straight-forward: “A text
equivalent for every non-text element shall be
provided”

– Others are trickier and are still being interpreted:
– Others are trickier and are still being interpreted:

“When a web page requires that an applet, plug-in or other application be present on the client system to interpret page content, the page must provide a link to a plug-in or applet that complies with (requirements for software applications and operating systems)” – Headquarters and others (e.g., GSA) have prepared
“When a web page requires that an applet, plug-in or
other application be present on the client system to
interpret page content, the page must provide a link to a
plug-in or applet that complies with (requirements for p l u g - i n
o r
a p p l e t
t h a t
c o m p l i e s
w i t h
( r e q u i r e m e n t s
f o r
software applications and operating systems)” s o f t w a r e
a p p l i c a t i o n s
a n d
o p e r a t i n g
s y s t e m s ) ”
– Headquarters and others (e.g., GSA) have prepared

excellent training materials in this area
excellent training materials in this area

– Key: follow the standards; do not rely solely on tools
– Key: follow the standards; do not rely solely on tools – K e y :
f o l l o w
t h e
s t a n d a r d s ;
d o
n o t
r e l y

NASA Web Requirements for Section 508
NASA Web Requirements for Section 508

• NASA CIO issued on June 19, 2001, policy for
• NASA CIO issued on June 19, 2001, policy for

compliance of NASA web pages with Section 508 – Provides guidance for both new and existing web pages – Establishes waiver process for undue burden – Requires Center-level plans to address bringing web
compliance of NASA web pages with Section 508
– Provides guidance for both new and existing web pages
– Establishes waiver process for undue burden
– Requires Center-level plans to address bringing web

pages into compliance
pages into compliance

• Initial plans due September 30, 2001 • Plan updates due every six months afterwards
• Initial plans due September 30, 2001
• Plan updates due every six months afterwards

– Policy was not prescriptive on plan format and level of
– Policy was not prescriptive on plan format and level of

detail
detail

– Submitted Center plans were generally good but varied
– Submitted Center plans were generally good but varied

widely in level of detail provided
widely in level of detail provided

NASA Web Requirements for Section 508
NASA Web Requirements for Section 508

• New Web pages
• New Web pages

– Effective the date of policy, new Web pages must be
– Effective the date of policy, new Web pages must be

compliant unless undue burden would result
compliant unless undue burden would result

– Undue burden waivers must be approved by the Center
– Undue burden waivers must be approved by the Center

CIO before new Web pages are posted
CIO before new Web pages are posted

• Concurrent email notification to the NASA CIO – New contracts that include Web work must require
• Concurrent email notification to the NASA CIO
– New contracts that include Web work must require

compliance
compliance

– Centers should modify existing contracts, as needed, to
– Centers should modify existing contracts, as needed, to

ensure new Web pages are compliant
ensure new Web pages are compliant

NASA Web Requirements for Section 508
NASA Web Requirements for Section 508

• Existing Web pages (three priorities)
• Existing Web pages (three priorities)

– Priority one (most important)
– Priority one (most important)

• Twenty most popular Web pages at every Center should
• Twenty most popular Web pages at every Center should

have been made compliant by September 30, 2001, unless undue burden waiver approved by NASA CIO • Update top twenty list on a scheduled basis and ensure
have been made compliant by September 30, 2001,
unless undue burden waiver approved by NASA CIO
• Update top twenty list on a scheduled basis and ensure

compliance
compliance

– Priority two
– Priority two

• Center Web pages that NASA employees, contractors, or the public use to enter information to request services or report a situation
• Center Web pages that NASA employees, contractors, or
the public use to enter information to request services or
report a situation

• Some purely informational pages may be more important: Centers should use their judgement
• Some purely informational pages may be more
important: Centers should use their judgement

NASA Web Requirements for Section 508
NASA Web Requirements for Section 508

• Existing Web pages (contd.)
• Existing Web pages (contd.)

– Priority three
– Priority three

• All Center web pages that are not Priority one or two – Consider making infrequently used and less important Web pages compliant as they are modified for other reasons
• All Center web pages that are not Priority one or two
– Consider making infrequently used and less important
Web pages compliant as they are modified for other
reasons

– Retire pages that are no longer needed rather than
– Retire pages that are no longer needed rather than

expend resources to make compliant
expend resources to make compliant

• New and existing Web pages
• New and existing Web pages

– “The Agency does not want to discourage innovative
– “The Agency does not want to discourage innovative

technical approaches for making information available via the Web”
technical approaches for making information available
via the Web”
